critique: The document is an executive order regarding civil service appointments. The tone is formal and authoritative. The primary goal is to ensure a fair and merit-based selection process for civil service positions. The order aims to prevent individuals from gaining classified civil service status simply because their name appears on a register, without undergoing a proper selection process. The language is precise and legalistic, reflecting the official nature of the document. The context is the administration of civil service appointments during World War II. The President likely wants to convey a sense of fairness, order, and efficiency in the civil service system. Initial scores: Joy: 1 (no explicit joy), Sadness: 1 (no explicit sadness), Anger: 1 (no explicit anger), Fear: 1 (no explicit fear), Disgust: 1 (no explicit disgust), Surprise: 1 (no explicit surprise). Revised scores: Joy: 2 (slight hope for a more fair system), Sadness: 1 (no explicit sadness), Anger: 1 (no explicit anger), Fear: 1 (no explicit fear), Disgust: 1 (no explicit disgust), Surprise: 2 (slight surprise at the change in procedure).
